The binding of an extracellular ligand to a <math alttext="G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein-coupled receptor in the plasma membrane of a cell triggers intracellular signaling (Figure 1, A). After ligand binding, <math alttext="G T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GTP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> replaces the <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> that is bound to <math alttext="G s alpha " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Gs</mtext><mi>α</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, a subunit of the <math alttext="G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein (Figure 1, B). This causes <math alttext="G s alpha " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Gs</mtext><mi>α</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> to activate other cellular proteins, including adenylyl cyclase that converts <math alttext="A T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>ATP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to cyclic <math alttext="A M P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>AMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> (<math alttext="c A M P " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>cAMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). The <math alttext="c A M P " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>cAMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> activates protein kinases (Figure 1, C). In cells that line the small intestine, a <math alttext="c A M P " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>cAMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>-activated protein kinase causes further signaling that ultimately results in the secretion of chloride ions (<math alttext="C l with a negative one charge" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>Cl</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) from the cells. Under normal conditions, <math alttext="G s alpha " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Gs</mtext><mi>α</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> hydrolyzes <math alttext="G T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GTP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="G D P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GDP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, thus inactivating adenylyl cyclase and stopping the signal (Figure 1, A). Figure 1. Under normal conditions, ligand binding to a <math alttext="G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein-coupled receptor results in chloride ion transport from an intestinal cell. Individuals infected with the bacterium Vibrio cholerae experience severe loss of water from the body (dehydration). This is due to the effects of the bacterial cholera toxin that enters intestinal cells. Scientists studied the effects of cholera toxin on four samples of isolated intestinal cell membranes containing the <math alttext="G" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>G</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> protein-related signal transduction components shown in Figure 1. <math alttext="G T P" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GTP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> was added to samples <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> only; cholera toxin was added to samples <math alttext="3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> only. The scientists then measured the amount of <math alttext="c A M P " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>cAMP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produced by the adenylyl cyclase in each sample (Table 1). (d) A drug is designed to bind to cholera toxin before it crosses the intestinal cell membrane. Scientists mix the drug with cholera toxin and then add this mixture and <math alttext="G T P " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>GTP</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to a sample of intestinal cell membranes. In a separate experiment, scientists engineer a mutant adenylyl cyclase that cannot be activated by <math alttext="G s alpha " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Gs</mtext><mi>α</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The scientists claim that cholera toxin will not cause excessive water loss from whole intestinal cells that contain the mutant adenylyl cyclase. Justify this claim.
